adverbs.description: infield (comparative more infield, superlative most infield)

entries.meaning: The area inside a racetrack or running track.

examples: Let’s keep this problem in the infield.

entries.meaning: (agriculture) An area to cultivate: a field
(baseball) The region of the field roughly bounded by the home plate, first base, second base and third base.
examples: They covered the infield with a tarp when it started to rain.

entries.meaning: (baseball) (as a modifier, functioning as an adjective) Of an event, happening in the infield.
examples: Jones ran out an infield single.

entries.meaning: (cricket) The region of the field roughly bounded by the wicket keeper, slips, gully, point, cover, mid off, mid on, midwicket and square leg.

verbs.description: infield (third-person singular simple present infields, present participle infielding, simple past and past participle infielded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To enclose (a piece of land); make a field of.
